quote: IF I SEE A PROBLEM, AND I CAN FIGURE OUT A FIX, THEN I’M GOING TO ADDRESS THAT PROBLEM
knownfor: Chef, & Activist for equitable and healthy food systems.
mathhero: Chefs like Kiki prepare food using recipes that include math:
funfact: Kiki founded a gourmet grocery store called “Farmers Hand” so her community could have access to food from local farms.
jobdescriptionbullets: Kiki Bokungu Louya is an award-winning chef from Detroit, Michigan.
Kiki's companies and restaurants are interested in providing communities healthy foods supplied by local farmers. Her organizations support the fair treatment of food and farm workers.
Kiki combines her love of math, problem solving, and science with her cooking skills.
Kiki competed on the TV show Top Chef: Portland.
references: Kiki Louya top chef portland detroit restaurateur.
Moskin, J. (2019, July 16). Black Chefs Changing Food in America.

quote: SE VEO UN PROBLEMA, Y PUEDO ENCONTRAR UNA SOLUCIÓN, ENTONCES VOY A ENFRENTAR ESE PROBLEMA
knownfor: Chef, & Activista para las sistemas de comida equitativos y saludables.
mathhero: Los chefs como Kiki preparan comida usando recetas que requieren del uso de conceptos mathemáticos como:
funfact: Kiki fundó una tienda gourmet llamada 'Farmers Hand' para que su comunidad tuviera acceso a alimentos de las granjas locales.
jobdescriptionbullets: Kiki Bokungu Louya es una chef de Detroit que ha recibido muchos premios.

Las empresas y restaurantes de Kiki están interesados en proveer a las comunidades con alimentos saludables proporcionados por agricultores locales. Sus organizaciones apoyan el comercio justo de los alimentos y el trato justo de los trabajadores agrícolas.
Kiki combina su pasión por las matemáticas, las ciencias, y encontrar soluciones a problemas con la concina.
Kiki compitió en el programa de televisión Top Chef: Portland.
references: Kiki Louya top chef portland detroit restaurateur.
Moskin, J. (2019, July 16). Black Chefs Changing Food in America.

quote: MATHEMATICS LITERACY IS A CIVIL RIGHTS ISSUE.
knownfor: The Algebra Project, & Civil Rights Movement leadership.
mathhero: In the Algebra Project students learn:
mathherobullet: To take their own words and pictures (“real talk”) and convert those ideas into mathematical expressions using symbols (“feature talk”)
To summarize situations visually using graphs and charts.
To expand on the arithmetic notion of “How many?” to include directions (“Which way?”) and dimensions seen in algebra.
jobdescriptionbullets: Bob Moses was best known for developing The Algebra Project. Algebra is often described as the language of summary. Bob viewed mastery of algebra as the first step to gaining access to educational and employment opportunities.
Bob used math literacy as a tool to organize the community. He learned this technique while registering people to vote during the Civil Rights Movement of the 1960s.

The Algebra Project helps students develop techniques to remove the mystery from math questions. Bob’s teachings help students realize symbols are created by someone, have a meaning, and are on the paper for a reason.

The Algebra Project helps students realize “the concept of being ‘smart’ is something that you become, it’s not something that you are. If I don’t know it now, then I’ll know it tomorrow, if I put in the effort.
references: Moses, R., Maxwell West, M., & Davis, F. E. (2009). Culturally Responsive Mathematics Education in the Algebra Project. In B. Greer, S. Mukhopadhyay, A. B. Powell, & S. Nelson-Barber (Eds.), Culturally responsive mathematics education (pp. 239-256). Routledge
Moses, R. P., & Cobb, C. E. (2001). Radical Equations: Civil Rights from Mississippi to the Algebra Project. Beacon Press

quote: I JUST ALWAYS LOVED IT. I THINK THAT’S WHAT HELPED ME GET TO WHERE I AM.
mathhero: Abraham uses math in many ways when he plays golf:
mathherobullet: He makes an estimate of the distance between him, the ball, and the hole.
Next, he analyzes the possible angles to hit the ball to keep it on the grass (
). A bad angle will make his ball land in a trap like tall grass, sand, or water.
Finally, he calculates the force with which to hit the ball to put it in the hole perfectly - or leave it as close as possible.
jobdescriptionbullets: Abraham Ancer is a professional golfer. A professional golfers’ job is to get the ball into each of the 18 holes on the golf course with the least amount of ball strokes.
Abraham’s father introduced him to golf at a very young age. He practiced at the local course in Reynosa, Mexico. Each hole he targets has a circumference of 4.5 inches or 11 centimeters.

Abraham is the fourth Mexican to win on the Professional Golfers’ Association (PGA) Tour. He is the first to win a world golf championship match. One of his greatest wishes is to make golf more accessible to all children regardless of their background.
references: Ancer, A. & Gabrielle Herzig (2021, May 10). How Abraham Ancer, with no coach, made it to the PGA Tour from a tiny town in Mexico. GolfDigest International. https://www.golfdigest.com/story/abraham-ancer-journeys-pga-tour
DP World Tour. (2021, August 8). Abraham Ancer becomes first Mexican to win a WGC | 2021 WGC - FedEx St. Jude International [Video]. YouTube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iuDFNtDnxZw

quote: FIGURE OUT WHAT YOU’RE REALLY PASSIONATE ABOUT AND WHAT GIVES YOU ENERGY.
knownfor: Designing software systems to quickly process large amounts of data
mathhero: Software engineers like Andrew use math to:
mathherobullet: Develop computer programs to solve complex problems.
Write rules for computers to follow.Computers decompose rules into strings of 1s and 0s.
Develop a coding language to provide computers instructions on how to operate.
jobdescriptionbullets: Andrew Ozor is a software engineer. A software engineer designs and writes programs for electronic devices.
Andrew designs software for lawyers to use to store and sort important legal data.
Andrew always wanted to create his own video games. He learned coding in college and discovered there were so many different things he could design beyond video games.
Andrew decided he wanted to focus on developing codes that help make systems easier for people to use.
references: GCFGlobal.org. (n.d.). Computer basics: What is a computer? https://edu.gcfglobal.org/en/computerbasics/what-is-a-computer/1/
